context: Thus, the functional role of purinergic signalling in modulating the activity of central sympathetic control circuits might have functional importance in conditions associated with increases in local concentration of ATP, such as during systemic hypoxia or hypercapnia. Cardiac vagal preganglionic motoneurons are also under purinergic control. These neurons are found in two medullary locations: in the dorsal vagal motonucleus and within and near the nucleus ambiguus of the ventrolateral medulla oblongata. Purinergic modulation of the latter population has been studied recently, demonstrating that ATP might presynaptically modulate both excitatory glutamatergic and inhibitory GABAergic and glycinergic inputs to these neurons. Functionally, during recovery from hypoxia, ATP (perhaps released by astrocytes), mediates respiratory-related enhancement of glutamatergic excitatory input to cardiac vagal preganglionic motoneurons. Conclusions ATP is a ubiquitous cellular energy source and intercellular messenger molecule that mediates purinergic signalling fundamental for the operation of the autonomic nervous system. Although purinergic receptors are arguably the most abundant receptors in living organisms, the fact that the same transmitter is involved at multiple steps of the autonomic reflex pathways – from the transduction of sensory information to neuroeffector transmission (illustrated in Figure 4 by the example of sympathoexcitatory arterial chemoreflex) – seems very interesting from the physiological and evolutionary points of view.
